description:
My brother Blair and I put this app together at a hackathon. We decided to follow through for fun and turn it into a live app on the marketplace. You can go download it from apple here:
http://itunes.apple.com/us/app/qr-sync/id469820330?ls=1&mt=8

It's a barcode scanner that will give you the ability to instantly share scan results to facebook and twitter, or create a google task with the scan result. The scan results will be placed on a map so you can see where you were when you scanned something, and if it's a product we can find at amazon we'll give you a buy link.
name: QR Sync

description: We needed a job board for the meetup group, Seattle Ruby on Rails - so I thought it would be fun to whip one up.  It was Erfon's need, and Dave's design - credits on the site.
name: Seattle Ruby Jobs

description:
Don't let your domain names expire! Or your client's domain names!

I manage hundreds of domains for clients and personal projects and found a great commercial product to monitor the expirations, but thought this would make a great open source product.
name: Domain Monitour

description: We went to the android meetup to learn android sdk to build apps and made this during the course of the meetup series.  It scratched an itch of mine.  I wanted to know who was calling me if they weren't in my address book.  What we learned in doing this is that MOST cell phone providers actually put your name in the database so we can get names for most cell phone callers that aren't in your address book!  Pretty cool.  We offer a free trial to get 5 incoming calls and see it work.  It won't get names for Verizon callers, and Verizon users have to be on Wi-Fi due to the network limitations.  Go download it for android.
name: Real Caller ID

description: We went to Techcrunch Disrupt 2011 and competed in the hackathon! This was our idea, basically a product to compete or supplement experian/transunion/etc by using social pressure and validations to build a new credit score system.
name: Social Credit Score

description:
Okay, you are at an event, and want to give something away. What do you do?

Have everyone put their name in a hat? Come up with some horrible way of choosing someone out of a crowd? We solved this problem at a hackathon and won first place.

Just head to giraffler.com, sign up, create a raffle, and you get a QR code you can put on a projector, or a short url you can tweet out - the audience visits the link and puts in a name or phone number, and the organizer presses 'pick winner'. Done.

Here is the presentation, fast forward 30+ seconds :)
From October 15, 2011
name: Giraffler - A Raffle App

description:
RepairShopr is our line-of-business app to enable repair shops (computer repair shops) to operate their business with ease.

Our system allows them to manage tickets, customers, field jobs, time tracking, and lots more in a hosted web-based system that is super simple to use.

It launched in July of 2012 to the public - go sign up to check it out!
name: Repair Shopr

description:
My wife and I entered a hackathon in Seattle called a wearables hackathon July 12th 2014. We built a potty training diaper that alerts you when it gets wet! We had a blast, and won! Paypal gave our team 3 Pebble watches. 

http://www.peepeealert.com/

http://www.peepeealert.com/#!how-we-did-it/c1159

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5_yesqwQs8k
name: PeePeeAlert

description: Our computer repair shop we started in 2003.  My first time really putting together a business.  Still running today and profitable. We sold this in July of 2014 to a loving new owner.
name: Dr PC Fix - Computer Repair Shop

description:
Supporting business IT needs from desktop support to network builds and Active Directory/Exchange support.

Desiree and I put a lot of time into building this business from 2007 to 2011. Currently Desiree runs this business.
name: All In Networks - Managed IT Services
